Unit-Modulus Wireless Federated Learning
Via Penalty Alternating Minimization

Shuai Wang∗,⋄, Dachuan Li⋄, Rui Wang∗, Qi Hao⋄, Yik-Chung Wu†, and Derrick Wing Kwan Ng⋆
∗Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Southern University of Science and Technology, China
⋄Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Southern University of Science and Technology, China
†Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong
⋆School of Electrical Engineering and Telecommunications, University of New South Wales, Australia
E-mail: wangs3@sustech.edu.cn, dachuanli86@gmail.com, wang.r@sustech.edu.cn,
hao.q@sustech.edu.cn, ycwu@eee.hku.hk, w.k.ng@unsw.edu.au This paper has been accepted for publication in IEEE Global Communications Conference 2021.
Abstract

Wireless federated learning (FL) is an emerging machine learning paradigm that trains a global parametric model from distributed datasets via wireless communications. This paper proposes a unit-modulus wireless FL (UMWFL) framework, which simultaneously uploads local model parameters and computes global model parameters via optimized phase shifting. The proposed framework avoids sophisticated baseband signal processing, leading to both low communication delays and implementation costs. A training loss bound is derived and a penalty alternating minimization (PAM) algorithm is proposed to minimize the nonconvex nonsmooth loss bound. Experimental results in the Car Learning to Act (CARLA) platform show that the proposed UMWFL framework with PAM algorithm achieves smaller training losses and testing errors than those of the benchmark scheme.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a promising technique to reduce the communication overhead while protecting the data privacy at users for effective machine learning [1]. Although FL was originally developed for wire-line connected systems [1], the development of mobile intelligent systems such as autonomous driving [2] calls for wireless connections between the server and users, giving rise to a new paradigm termed wireless FL or edge FL [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]. However, the convergence of wireless FL may require an exceedingly long time due to limited capacity of wireless channels during the uplink model aggregation step. To reduce the transmission delay, various wireless FL designs have been proposed, which are mainly categorized into digital modulation [3, 4, 5] and analog modulation [6, 7, 8, 9] methods.

For digital modulation systems, data from different users are multiplexed either in the time or the frequency domain [10]. Current works on delay reduction focus on reducing 1) the number of model aggregation iterations [3], 2) the number of users [4], or 3) the number of bits for representing the gradient of back propagation in each iteration [5]. However, since these strategies involve various approximations of the FL procedure, the performance of learning would be degraded inevitably. On the other hand, the key advantage of analog modulation [6, 7, 8, 9] over digital modulation arises from the ground-breaking idea of over-the-air computation (AirComp). Specifically, if multiple users upload their local parameters simultaneously, a superimposed signal, which represents a weighted sum of individual model parameters, is observed at the edge server. By performing the minimum mean square error (MMSE) detection on the superimposed signal, an estimate of the global parameter vector can be obtained, thereby significantly shortening the required transmission time. However, due to channel fading and noise in wireless systems, AirComp employed in single-antenna systems [6, 7] could result in large error in the estimation of global model parameters at the edge server, leading to slow convergence of FL iterations. As a remedy, adopting MIMO beamforming [8, 9] could reduce the parameter transmission error by aligning the beams carrying the local parameters’ information to the same desired spatial direction. Nonetheless, the current transmit and receive beamforming designs in MIMO AirComp systems involve exceedingly high radio frequency (RF) chain costs and high computational complexities [8, 9], preventing their practical implementation.

To fill the research gap, this paper proposes the unit-modulus wireless FL (UMWFL) framework which integrates AirComp and unit-modulus analog beamforming. Specifically, the edge users possess a number of training data for local model updates. Then, the trained model parameters are uploaded to the server via analog modulation. To reduce the implementation costs, the edge server does not process the received model parameters at the baseband. Instead, it applies a phase shift network in the RF domain and an RF sampling module to connect received antennas and transmit antennas for global model updates. Upon receiving the broadcast, all users feed the received signals to an analog demodulator for parameter extraction. Note that our UMWFL framework can significantly reduce the required RF chains in MIMO FL systems, thereby reducing the associated hardware and energy costs. The proposed UMWFL framework also alleviates the straggler effects in both model uploading and broadcasting procedures. On the other hand, despite the UMWFL problem being highly nonconvex, a large-scale optimization algorithm, termed penalty alternating minimization (PAM), is developed. Experimental results show that the learning performance of the proposed PAM significantly outperforms the benchmark scheme without phase optimization.

II Unit Modulus Wireless Federated Learning

We consider a UMWFL system shown in Fig. 1, which consists of an edge server equipped with N𝑁N antennas and K𝐾K single-antenna mobile users. The training of UMWFL model parameters (i.e., solving (II)) in the considered edge system is naturally a distributed and iterative procedure, where each iteration involves four steps: 1) updating the local parameter vectors (𝐱1,⋯,𝐱K)subscript𝐱1⋯subscript𝐱𝐾(\mathbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{K}) using {𝒟1,⋯,𝒟K}subscript𝒟1⋯subscript𝒟𝐾\{\mathcal{D}_{1},\cdots,\mathcal{D}_{K}\} at users (1,⋯,K)1⋯𝐾(1,\cdots,K), respectively; 2) transforming the local parameters (𝐱1,⋯,𝐱K)subscript𝐱1⋯subscript𝐱𝐾(\mathbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{K}) into transmit symbols (𝐬1,⋯,𝐬K)subscript𝐬1⋯subscript𝐬𝐾(\mathbf{s}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{s}_{K}) via power and phase designs; 3) aggregating (𝐱1,⋯,𝐱k)subscript𝐱1⋯subscript𝐱𝑘(\mathbf{x}_{1},\cdots,\mathbf{x}_{k}) in an analog manner at the edge server; and 4) broadcasting the results to users. The details for the i𝑖i-th iteration of UMWFL are elaborated below.

III Training Loss Minimization

Ideally, the optimization of {𝐅[i],rk[i],tk[i]}superscript𝐅delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘delimited-[]𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘delimited-[]𝑖\{\mathbf{F}^{[i]},r_{k}^{[i]},t_{k}^{[i]}\} should be performed to minimize the training loss, i.e., min⁡Λ​(𝐱k[i+1]​(0))Λsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖10\min~{}\Lambda(\mathbf{x}_{k}^{[i+1]}(0)). However, the analytical expression of 𝔼​[Λ​(𝐱k[i+1]​(0))]𝔼delimited-[]Λsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖10\mathbb{E}\left[\Lambda(\mathbf{x}_{k}^{[i+1]}(0))\right], where the expectation is taken over receiver noises and model parameters, is usually challenging to derive. As a compromise approach, we resort the use of the upper bound of the expectation of 𝔼​[Λ​(𝐱k[i+1]​(0))−Λ​(𝜽∗)]𝔼delimited-[]Λsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖10Λsuperscript𝜽\mathbb{E}\left[\Lambda(\mathbf{x}_{k}^{[i+1]}(0))-\Lambda(\bm{\theta}^{*})\right] as a metric to capture the degradation on training loss. The upper bound depends on the MSE of the model parameters’ estimation 𝔼​[‖𝐱k[i+1]​(0)−𝜽[i]‖22]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptsuperscript𝐱delimited-[]𝑖1𝑘0superscript𝜽delimited-[]𝑖22\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathbf{x}^{[i+1]}_{k}(0)-\bm{\theta}^{[i]}\|_{2}^{2}\right] where

Proof.

We first derive the upper bound between consecutive parameter vectors. Then the upper bound between consecutive losses can be derived. Finally, we derive the upper bound of the sequence of loss function values. Please refer to [13] for detailed derivations. ∎

Theorem 1 shows a diminishing A[i′]→0→superscript𝐴delimited-[]superscript𝑖′0A^{[i^{\prime}]}\rightarrow 0 for a large i−i′𝑖superscript𝑖′i-i^{\prime}, meaning that the impact from earlier UMWFL iterations vanishes as the UMWFL continues. On the other hand, if 𝕄​𝕊​𝔼k[i′]→0→𝕄𝕊subscriptsuperscript𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑖′𝑘0\mathbb{MSE}^{[i^{\prime}]}_{k}\rightarrow 0 for all k𝑘k, then Λ​(𝐱k[i+1])Λsuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑘delimited-[]𝑖1\Lambda(\mathbf{x}_{k}^{[i+1]}) is an unbiased estimate of Λ​(𝜽∗)Λsuperscript𝜽\Lambda(\bm{\theta}^{*}). This demonstrates the effectiveness of UMWFL in the asymptotic regime. The convexity and smoothness in Assumption 1 have been adopted in most loss bound analysis of FL (e.g., [4]). Although it seems to be restrictive for some realistic applications, analysis under Assumption 1 could provide important insights of the behavior of UMWFL in nonconvex cases.

Based on Theorem 1, the training loss minimization in UMWFL systems is formulated as

Problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is generally NP-hard due to the unit-modulus constraints [11, 12]. In addition, the coupling between variables {rk,tk}subscript𝑟𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘\{r_{k},t_{k}\} and 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F} introduces nonlinearity and nonconvexity to the considered problem. Finally, the large dimension of 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F} call for the design of low-complexity algorithms in the scenario with massive numbers of antennas.

IV Penalty Alternating Minimization for UMWFL

In this section, the PAM algorithm, which consists of two nested layers of iterations (i.e., an outer-layer iteration and an inner-layer iteration), will be proposed to optimize the system performance. Below we first introduce the outer-layer iteration.

IV-A Outer-Layer Iteration Via Alternating Optimization

To resolve the coupling between variables {rk,tk}subscript𝑟𝑘subscript𝑡𝑘\{r_{k},t_{k}\} and 𝐅𝐅\mathbf{F}, this paper adopts an alternating optimization framework [15], which optimizes one design variable at a time with others being fixed. Starting with an initial solution {𝐅(0),rk(0),tk(0)}superscript𝐅0superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑘0superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘0\{\mathbf{F}^{(0)},r_{k}^{(0)},t_{k}^{(0)}\}, the entire procedure solving problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} for the (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)-th outer iteration, ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n, can be elaborated below:

On the other hand, problem (14c) is a convex optimization problem, which can be solved with a complexity of 𝒪​(K3.5)𝒪superscript𝐾3.5\mathcal{O}(K^{3.5}) via CVX, a Matlab software package for solving convex problems based on interior point method (IPM). Consequently, the key challenge is to tackle the nonconvex problem (14a).

While problem (14a) can be transformed into a convex problem via semidefinite relaxation (SDR), the computational complexity for solving the SDR problem is at least 𝒪​(N7)𝒪superscript𝑁7\mathcal{O}\left(N^{7}\right) [16]. Since N𝑁N is usually much larger than K𝐾K, this method is not desirable. In the following, a new algorithm termed PAM, which decomposes (14a) into smaller subproblems that are solved by closed-form updates, is proposed for achieving both excellent performance and significantly lower computational complexities.

To handle the nonseparable objective function, variable splitting of 𝐟𝐟\mathbf{f} is proposed such that 𝐟=𝐮1=⋯=𝐮K𝐟subscript𝐮1⋯subscript𝐮𝐾\mathbf{f}=\mathbf{u}_{1}=\cdots=\mathbf{u}_{K}, where {𝐮k}subscript𝐮𝑘\{\mathbf{u}_{k}\} are auxilliary variables. For the newly introduced equality constraints, they can be transformed into quadratic penalties in the objective function [18]. Thus, 𝒫Fsubscript𝒫𝐹\mathcal{P}_{F} is approximately transformed into

where ρ𝜌\rho is a penalty parameter for fine-tuning. It can be proved that 𝒫Fsubscript𝒫𝐹\mathcal{P}_{F} and (21) are equivalent problems as ρ→+∞→𝜌\rho\rightarrow+\infty [18]. However, this case also leads to the gradient norm of the objective function of (21) being infinite, making (21) difficult to solve. Therefore, ρ𝜌\rho controls the tradeoff between approximation error and difficulty in solving (21).

We address (21) using alternating minimization, in which the cost function is iteratively minimized with respect to one variable whereas the others are fixed. where m𝑚m is the inner iteration index. It can be verified that the objective function of (21) is strongly convex. Therefore, despite the non-differentiability of the objective, the alternating minimization (22a)–(22c) is guaranteed to converge to a stationary point of (21) [15]. The iterative procedure stops until m𝑚m reaches the maximum iteration number m=Mmax𝑚subscript𝑀maxm=M_{\mathrm{max}}.

The remaining question is how to solve (22a)–(22c) optimally. We notice that problems (22a) and (22b) are standard least squares problems, thus their solutions are given by the following closed-form expressions

IV-C Summary and Complexity Analysis of PAM

In summary, the complete PAM algorithm for solving problem 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is summarized in Algorithm 1. The computational complexity (CP) is dominated by the steps at lines 4–6 in Algorithm 1, of which the CPs are given by 𝒪​(K​N2)𝒪𝐾superscript𝑁2\mathcal{O}(KN^{2}), 𝒪​(K​N2)𝒪𝐾superscript𝑁2\mathcal{O}(KN^{2}), and 𝒪​(N2)𝒪superscript𝑁2\mathcal{O}(N^{2}), respectively. Therefore, the total CP of PAM is 𝒪​(Nmax​Mmax​K​N2)𝒪subscript𝑁maxsubscript𝑀max𝐾superscript𝑁2\mathcal{O}(N_{\rm{max}}M_{\rm{max}}KN^{2})

V Results and Discussions

This section presents simulation results to verify the performance of the proposed scheme. We consider the object detection task in autonomous vehicle (AV) systems [2, 20]. This task involves three main steps: 1) distributed dataset generation and storage at each vehicle; 2) collecting labels from nearby road-side infrastructures (RSIs); 3) federated learning within a vehicle platoon. The three steps are executed sequentially and may not occur in the same place. The case of K=3𝐾3K=3 is simulated and the number of total UMWFL iterations is set to 151515. The average precision at intersection of union (IoU) equal to 0.5 is used for performance evaluation. Besides the proposed PAM algorithm, we also simulate a baseline scheme, which sets 𝐅=𝐈N𝐅subscript𝐈𝑁\mathbf{F}=\mathbf{I}_{N} and optimize {tk,rk}subscript𝑡𝑘subscript𝑟𝑘\{t_{k},r_{k}\} using (14b) and (14c).

For dataset generation and storage, it can be realized via a physical-world testbed; but this involves high implementation costs. Car Learning to Act (CARLA) [21] is a widely-accepted unreal-engine platform that provides complex urban driving scenarios and high 3D rendering quality such that the AV object detection can be prototyped in virtual-reality. Hence, in this paper, all the datasets are generated by CARLA. In particular, we employ CARLA to generate 292929 vehicles in the “Town05” map, among which 333 are autonomous driving vehicles that can generate the point-cloud data at a frequency of 101010 frames/s. The entire dataset consists of 600600600 frames at each vehicle, where 100100100 frames are used for training and 500500500 frames are used for testing. Fig. 2a illustrates the bird eye view of the simulated world and the locations of all vehicles. The datasets at different vehicles are non-i.i.d. due to various fields of views. For label collection, it is assumed that each vehicle can obtain the ground truth label from its nearby RSI. The labels should satisfy (Karlsruhe Institute of Technology and Toyota Technological Institute) KITTI formats. This can be realized by processing the raw data generated from CARLA using the Python scripts in [2, 23]. Finally, to simulate the vehicle platoon federated learning, we need to specify the local model and the communication parameters. Specifically, the sparsely embedded convolutional detection (SECOND) neural network [22] is adopted for object detection. Each round of local training processes 100100100 frames and the Adam optimizer is adopted with a learning rate of 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. The number of local updates is E=1𝐸1E=1. The model training is implemented by PyTorch using Python 3.8 on a Linux server with an NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU. For the communication model, the pathloss of the user k𝑘k is set to ϱk=−40​dBsubscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘40dB\varrho_{k}=-40\,\mathrm{dB}, and 𝐡ksubscript𝐡𝑘\mathbf{h}_{k} and 𝐠ksubscript𝐠𝑘\mathbf{g}_{k} are generated according to 𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,ϱk​𝐈N)𝒞𝒩0subscriptitalic-ϱ𝑘subscript𝐈𝑁\mathcal{CN}(\mathbf{0},\varrho_{k}\mathbf{I}_{N}). The edge server is equipped with N=8𝑁8N=8 antennas. The power scaling factor γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1 and the maximum transmit powers at users are P0=1​Wsubscript𝑃01WP_{0}=1~{}\mathrm{W} (i.e., 30​dBm30dBm30\,\mathrm{dBm}). The noise powers at the server and users are set as −80​dBm80dBm-80\,\mathrm{dBm}, which capture the effects of thermal noise, receiver noise, and interference.

Performance. Firstly, it can be seen from Fig. 2b that the training loss of the baseline scheme fluctuates violently at the iterations 777 and 111111, because the model errors are non-negligible due to the strong multi-path fading at these communication rounds. In contrast, via proper phase shifting at the server, such a multi-path fading is effectively alleviated by the proposed scheme. Therefore, the training loss of the proposed UMWFL with the PAM algorithm converges to a significantly smaller value than that of the baseline scheme. Secondly, as shown in Fig. 2c, the average precision region of the proposed PAM scheme encloses that of the baseline scheme, which implies that the PAM scheme achieves higher learning performance on all the testing datasets. Particularly, the performance improvement is between 10%percent1010\% and 50%percent5050\%. Lastly, the qualitative performance of the proposed and baseline schemes are compared in Fig. 3. It can be observed that the proposed UMWFL with PAM detects all the objects correctly. However, the baseline scheme misses a turning car at vehicle 111, misses an occluded car at vehicle 222, and outputs an inaccurate detection at vehicle 333. This demonstrates the non-robustness of wireless FL if no phase optimization is performed. In contrast, if non-unit-modulus beamforming optimization is employed, significantly higher implementation costs are involved. The proposed UMWFL can effectively strike a balance between the robustness of the FL and the cost at the server, which is a competitive technology in real edge FL implementations.

VI Conclusion

This paper proposed the UMWFL scheme to support simultaneous transmission of local model parameters. The training loss bound was derived and a low-complexity large-scale optimization algorithm was proposed to minimize the training loss. The performance of the UMWFL framework with the proposed optimization algorithm was verified by using the CARLA autonomous driving platform. It was found that the UMWFL scheme achieves robust FL performance and low communication costs.
